Technical Assistance Report 
Project Number: 46089  
Policy and Advisory Technical Assistance (PATA) 
December 2012 
 
 
 
People’s Republic of China: Biodiversity Strategy and 
Action Plan for Yunnan Province 
(Cofinanced by the Multi-Donor Trust Fund under the Water 
Financing Partnership Facility) 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 22 November 2012) 
Currency unit  –  yuan (CNY) 
CNY1.00  =  $0.1606 
$1.00  =  CNY6.2258 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
BCLO  –  biodiversity conservation liaison office 
BSAP  –  biodiversity strategy and action plan 
GIS  –  geographic information system 
IWRM  –  integrated water resources management 
NBSAP  –  national biodiversity strategy and action plan 
PRC  –  People’s Republic of China 
TA  –  technical assistance 
YEPD  –  Yunnan Environment Protection Department  
YPG  –  Yunnan provincial government 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
Type  –  Policy and advisory technical assistance (PATA) 
Targeting classification  –  Targeted intervention – Geographic (TI-G)  
Sector (subsectors)  –  Agriculture and natural resources (land-based natural resources 
management,  water-based  natural  resources  management, 
forestry) 
Theme (subthemes)  –  Environmental sustainability (natural resources conservation, 
global  and  regional  transboundary  environmental  concerns), 
capacity development (institutional development) 
Location (impact)  –  Rural (high), urban (low), national (medium), regional (medium) 
Partnership  –  Multi-Donor Trust Fund under the Water Financing Partnership 
Facility 
 
NOTE 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
Vice-President  S. Groff, Operations 2 
Director General  R. Wihtol, East Asia Department (EARD) 
Director  Y. L. Feng, Environment, Natural Resources, and Agriculture Division, EARD 
   
Team leader  M. Bezuijen, Environment Specialist, EARD 
Team members  K. Guy, Young Professional, EARD 
C. Yeager, Climate Change Specialist, EARD 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the 2011 country programming review mission, the Government of the People’s 
Republic of China (PRC) requested policy and advisory technical assistance (TA) from the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) for preparing a biodiversity strategy and action plan (BSAP) for 
Yunnan Province.1 The TA is a 2012 standby in ADB’s country operations business plan, 2012–
2014 for the PRC. In July 2012, an ADB mission visited the PRC and reached an understanding 
with  the  government  on  TA  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  cost  estimates  and  financing  plan, 
implementation arrangements, and consultants’ terms of reference. The design and monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Biodiversity conservation in the PRC is conducted under the framework of the national 
biodiversity strategy and action plan (NBSAP), 2011–2030.2 Released in 2011, the NBSAP sets 
targets for national conservation and commits provinces to prepare provincial BSAPs. Three 
BSAPs have been or are nearly completed, for Chongqing, Guangxi, and Sichuan. Others are in 
progress, but many provinces have little technical guidance on how to develop these plans. 
 
3.  Yunnan Province is a global biodiversity hotspot. Located in the southwestern PRC, it is 
the most species-rich province in the nation, with over 50% of the PRC’s vascular plant and 
vertebrate fauna species, 16% of its endemic flora, and 73% of its priority protected animals 
(243 of 335 species).3 Parts of Yunnan are listed in the NBSAP as high-priority regions for 
biodiversity. Ecosystems in the province range from subtropical lowland forests near sea level to 
temperate forests, glaciers, and high-altitude wetlands at over 6,000 meters on the Qinghai––
Xizang Zizhiqu 4 plateau. Yunnan’s biodiversity values are matched by its cultural richness: 25 
of the PRC’s 55 ethnic minorities reside in Yunnan, of which 15 are found nowhere else.5 The 
social, economic, and spiritual livelihood of these groups is closely linked with biodiversity. 
Yunnan is one of the PRC’s poorest provinces, with over 75% of the population engaged in 
agriculture  and  5.6  million  people  earning  an  annual  income  below  CNY300.6 Extensive 
economic development is under way, and central Yunnan is highlighted in the PRC’s Twelfth 
Five-Year Plan, 2011–2015 for a new round of development.7 Biodiversity and minority cultures 
drive a rapidly expanding tourism industry. However, this growth is at risk. Yunnan’s biodiversity 
is under severe threat, largely from unsustainable development that is causing the landscape-
level loss of natural habitats and declines in species populations. 
 
4.  Yunnan has some of the PRC’s most important hydrological resources, encompassing 
parts of the headwaters and lower reaches of six major rivers: the Dulong (Irrawaddy), Lancang 
                                                
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 7 November 2012. As agreed with 
the executing agency, the original TA title, Strategy and Action Plan for Biodiversity Protection in Yunnan, has 
been amended to reflect standard terminology for a biodiversity strategy and action plan. 
2  Ministry of Environmental Protection. 2010. China Biodiversity Conservation Strategy and Action Plan, 2011–2030. 
Beijing. 
3  Y. Yang et al. 2004. Biodiversity and biodiversity conservation in Yunnan, China. Biodiversity and Conservation 13. 
pp. 813–826. 
4  Also known as the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau. 
5  J. Xu et al. 2005. Integrating Sacred Knowledge for Conservation: Cultures and Landscapes in Southwest China. 
Ecology and Society 10. pp. 1–25. 
6  J. Li, C. Luo, and N. de Klerk. 2008. Trends in Infant/Child Mortality and Life Expectancy in Indigenous Populations 
in Yunnan Province, China. Australian and New Zealand Journal of Public Health 32. pp. 216–223. 
7  State Council of the PRC. 2011. Twelfth Five-Year Plan of the People’s Republic of China, 2011–2015. Beijing 
(unofficial English translation by the Delegation of the European Union in the People’s Republic of China). 
See: http://cbi.typepad.com/china_direct/2011/05/chinas-twelfth-five-new-plan-the-full-english-version.html

2   
(Mekong), Nu Jiang (Salween), Jinsha (Changhong), Hong (Red), and Nanpan (Pearl). These 
rivers extend for over 1,000 km, through other provinces in the PRC or the downstream nations 
of Cambodia, the Lao People’s Democratic Republic, Myanmar, Thailand, and Viet Nam. As 
part of the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS),8 Yunnan shares over 4,000 km of international 
borders  with  Myanmar,  the  Lao  People’s  Democratic  Republic,  and  Viet  Nam.  These 
transboundary regions and rivers support globally significant wetlands and forests and provide 
critical ecosystem services to over 100 million people. Yunnan thus plays a critical role in 
maintaining regional forest and water resources for five nations in addition to the PRC. 
 
5.  No  analysis  of  provincial  conservation  priorities  has  been  undertaken  for  Yunnan. 
Priority-setting studies have been conducted for some landscapes and species, especially in 
northwestern and southern Yunnan, and provide a partial foundation for conservation planning. 
Despite this, conservation efforts are skewed to some landscapes and high-priority species, 
devoting less attention to other sites and species. The provincial protected area system does 
not correlate with species richness, endemism, or threat, such that some reserves have little 
conservation value while some important sites lack protection.9 
 
6.  In 2011, in response to the NBSAP, the Yunnan Environment Protection Department 
(YEPD) commissioned the preparation of a draft provincial biodiversity strategy, 2012–2030 by 
the Academy of Biodiversity Conservation Research of Southwest Forestry University. The 
public release of the final draft is planned for December 2012, but the draft table of contents of 
what is still an internal government document, provided by the YEPD, indicates that the strategy 
will describe some of Yunnan’s priority species and crosscutting links with integrated water 
resources  management  (IWRM),  poverty  alleviation,  tourism,  community  livelihoods,  and 
climate change. Preliminary reviews of the draft by the YEPD, national experts, and civil society 
organizations have raised concerns about (i) the lack of a rigorous technical approach based on 
international best practice to identify and rank conservation priorities for species and sites, (ii) 
the need to revise and strengthen the draft strategy, and (iii) the need for a 5-year action plan to 
begin implementing the strategy under the Thirteenth Five-Year Plan, 2016–2020. The Yunnan 
provincial government has concluded that preparing an effective BSAP requires the application 
of international good practices in conservation planning and additional funding. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The TA will facilitate the preparation of a BSAP for Yunnan Province. It will (i) implement 
a systematic planning process to identify biodiversity conservation priorities; (ii) revise the draft 
provincial strategy, 2012–2030; and (iii) prepare a 5-year action plan to implement the strategy 
during Yunnan’s 13th plan. It will identify priority projects, a budget for the first 5 years of BSAP 
implementation, and sources of financing. TA completion will coincide with the preparation of 
Yunnan’s 13th plan, providing a timely opportunity for the BSAP to facilitate the integration of 
biodiversity conservation into sector plans. For this TA, “biodiversity” refers only to vascular 
plants (those with tissues that circulate nutrients through the plant) and vertebrate fauna (birds, 
mammals, amphibians, reptiles, and fish) and their habitats. Other biodiversity is beyond the TA 
scope. The BSAP will strengthen conservation in Yunnan by 
(i)  providing a provincial framework that supports the NBSAP; 
                                                
8  The Greater Mekong Subregion encompasses Cambodia, the Lao People’s Democratic Republic, Myanmar, 
Thailand, and Viet Nam, as well as, in the PRC, Yunnan Province and the Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region. 
9  H. Xu et al. 2008. Biodiversity Congruence and Conservation Strategies: A National Test. BioScience 58. pp. 632–
639.

3 
(ii)  identifying species and sites of highest provincial conservation priority; 
(iii)  designing  a  conservation  network  of  terrestrial  and  wetland  habitats to  yield 
optimal results for conservation; 
(iv)  strengthening  the  capacity  of  the  YEPD  to  plan  and  prioritize  conservation 
initiatives,  particularly  by  providing  technical  skills  in  systematic  conservation 
planning and species ranking, which can be applied to other species and sites in 
Yunnan beyond the TA; 
(v)  promoting the mobilization of funding sources for biodiversity conservation; and 
(vi)  developing strategies and projects that link biodiversity conservation with related 
issues,  particularly  IWRM,  poverty  alleviation,  climate  change  adaptation, 
improved management of soils and forests, and the importance of community-led 
initiatives. 
 
8.  The  expected  impact  of  the  TA  is  improved  management  of  natural  resources, 
particularly biodiversity, in Yunnan Province. It is expected that by 2020 (i) the 5-year action 
plan will be incorporated into provincial sector plans, (ii) about 10 new management activities 
identified by the TA will be implemented in 10 conservation areas, and (iii) none of the highest-
priority vertebrate fauna identified in the TA will have become extinct in Yunnan. 
 
9.  The expected outcome of the TA is an established provincial framework for biodiversity 
conservation in Yunnan Province. This is to address the development problem that conservation 
efforts in Yunnan are not being planned or implemented systematically or efficiently. By 2014, 
the BSAP is expected to be approved by the biodiversity conservation liaison office (BCLO), a 
high-level provincial committee, and the amount in the YEPD’s annual fiscal budget allocated to 
biodiversity conservation from 2015 is expected to increase by about 10%. 
 
10.  The BSAP will contribute to national and international conservation objectives. The TA 
supports the goals of the PRC’s 12th plan, 2011–2015 which emphasizes the importance of 
biodiversity conservation; the NBSAP, which requires provinces to prepare BSAPs; and over 10 
other national strategies up to 2050 that include targets for threatened species, protected areas, 
forests, wetlands, poverty alleviation, and ethnic minorities. Internationally, the TA supports the 
goals of the Convention on Biological Diversity, to which the PRC is a signatory, and the 
People’s Republic of China–Association of Southeast Asian Nations Strategy on Environmental 
Protection  Cooperation,  2009–2015,  which  promotes  regional  collaboration  for  biodiversity 
conservation. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The expected outputs of the TA are (i) an analysis of biological conservation priorities for 
Yunnan Province completed, (ii) a comprehensive BSAP for Yunnan Province prepared, and (iii) 
government capacity in conservation planning strengthened. The TA will (i) identify priority 
species; (ii) analyze likely threats, including climate change, and propose how to mitigate them 
and strengthen resilience; (iii) analyze gaps in the protected area network and recommend how 
to address them; (iv) provide training in conservation planning; and (v) prepare the final draft 
BSAP. 
 
12.  The TA will be implemented over 18 months. During months 1 and 2, the YEPD and TA 
consultants will (i) review the current institutional framework, sector biodiversity plans, and 
previous  priority-setting  exercises  and  conservation  initiatives  in  Yunnan;  (ii)  assess  local 
capacity  in  conservation  planning;  (iii)  compile  necessary  data  and  geographic  information

4   
system data layers; and (iv) facilitate the establishment of a working group that includes experts 
and civil society organizations to develop the BSAP. 
 
13.  From months 3 to 9, the YEPD and TA consultants will (i) identify species and sites of 
highest provincial priority, based on a technical ranking of selected vertebrate fauna, vascular 
plant species, and sites; (ii) prepare geographic information system data layers and maps; (iii) 
recommend how to strengthen the provincial conservation network of terrestrial and wetland 
habitats,  based  on  existing  protected  area  coverage,  the  presence  of  target  species  and 
ecosystems, management status, and the potential impacts of climate change; and (iv) initiate 
training  to  strengthen  the  capacity  of  the  YEPD  and  other  natural  resource  management 
agencies in conservation planning and implementing the BSAP. 
 
14.  During months 10 to 18, the YEPD and TA consultants will (i) hold provincial workshops 
to inform and jointly review TA results; (ii) develop management strategies for priority species 
and sites, including determining specific projects to be implemented under the 5-year plan; (iii) 
develop sector strategies, especially to establish links on such crosscutting themes as IWRM, 
poverty alleviation, and climate change; (iv) develop a financial assessment for the BSAP, 
including sustainable and innovative sources of funding; (v) develop budget requirements and 
allocation; (vi) develop an implementation framework; and (vii) prepare a comprehensive BSAP. 
ADB and YEPD, supported by the TA consultants, will jointly prepare a knowledge product on 
the BSAP geared toward policy and decision makers.   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $660,000, of which $400,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources) and $200,000 by the 
Multi-Donor Trust Fund10 under the Water Financing Partnership Facility to be administered by 
ADB. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of office accommodation, 
domestic  transport,  remuneration  and  per  diem  for  counterpart  staff,  and  other  in-kind 
contributions. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  The  YEPD  will  be  the  executing  agency  for  the  TA.  The  YEPD  is  responsible  for 
coordinating the development and implementation of provincial environmental policies, including 
biodiversity conservation, and has shown strong capacity to execute ADB-assisted projects. 
Since 1995, the YEPD has been the executing agency for the Yunnan component of the ADB 
Greater Mekong Subregion Biodiversity Corridors Conservation Initiative. It is now administering 
the Yunnan component of phase 2 of this initiative and is familiar with ADB procurement and 
financial management procedures. 
 
17.  A TA management office will be established in the YEPD to administer the day-to-day 
activities of the TA and coordinate with ADB. The YEPD will provide office space, access to 
communications and copiers, and logistical support for TA implementation. The director of the 
TA management office will manage and liquidate funds provided by ADB and the government 
for training and workshops. 
 
18.  Provincial  decision-making for  biodiversity  conservation  in  Yunnan  is guided  by  the 
biodiversity conservation liaison committee, a group comprising the most senior officials of the 
                                                
10  Contributors: the governments of Australia, Austria, Norway, Spain, and Switzerland.

5 
Yunnan provincial government. Its activities are administered through the BCLO, which brings 
together senior representatives of the YEPD and the forestry, agriculture, land and resources, 
and finance departments. The BCLO will be the steering committee for the TA. The biodiversity 
conservation liaison committee and the BCLO are established structures within the Yunnan 
provincial government and provide a strong framework for TA implementation. The BCLO will 
meet at the inception, midterm, and final stages of TA implementation and when important TA 
outputs are produced, and it will ensure that the committee is kept updated on TA progress. 
 
19.  The tentative starting date for the TA is 1 April 2013 and the closing date 30 September 
2014. A consultant team hired through the TA will conduct most of the technical work to achieve 
the  outputs. The team will  be  supported  by  the  YEPD  and  a  working group  of additional 
resource personnel comprising local experts, civil society organizations, and other stakeholders 
as necessary, to help address specific topics or issues. The activities of the consultant team and 
working group will focus on technical assessments, surveys, workshops, capacity development, 
and facilitating the participatory development of TA outputs. Five reports will be prepared during 
the TA: inception, midterm, and final TA progress reports prepared 4 weeks, 9 months, and 18 
months, respectively, after TA commencement; the draft BSAP, prepared 15 months after TA 
commencement; and a knowledge product prepared 18 months after TA commencement. The 
reports will be subject to review by ADB and the government. The TA progress reports and 
knowledge product will be written in English and translated into Chinese. The draft BSAP will be 
written in Chinese and translated into English. The outline terms of reference for consultants is 
in Appendix 3, and the outline of the draft BSAP is in Appendix 4. 
 
20.  The TA consultants will be engaged through a firm and provide 4.5 person-months of 
international and 32.25 person-months of national specialist services. ADB will engage the 
consultants following its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time). The consulting firm will be selected using simplified technical proposals and quality- and 
cost-based selection with a quality–cost weighing ratio of 90:10. This high weighting for quality 
is justified by the technical complexity of the TA, which requires interdisciplinary specialist skills 
in biodiversity, climate change, IWRM, conservation financing, and specialist software, and is 
necessary  to  ensure  that  international  standards  of  conservation  planning  are  achieved. 
Equipment for the TA will be procured following ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as 
amended from time to time) and handed over to the YEPD upon TA completion. Disbursement 
under the TA will be in line with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as 
amended from time to time), with Water Financing Partnership Facility funds front-loaded. ADB 
will field inception, midterm, and final review missions to review TA progress and will maintain 
regular communications with the YEPD and the consultancy firm throughout the TA. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $200,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Multi-Donor Trust Fund under the Water Financing Partnership 
Facility; and (ii) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant 
basis to the Government of the People’s Republic of China for the Biodiversity Strategy and 
Action Plan for Yunnan Province, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

is estimated to account for 10% of the total TA cost. Funding from the Multi-Donor Trust Fund will be front-loaded.

Source: Asian Development Bank estimates.

10  Appendix 3 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  A consulting firm will be engaged for the technical assistance (TA). The successful firm 
will have (i) an established presence of at least 10 years in Yunnan Province of the People’s 
Republic of China (PRC); (ii) demonstrated expertise in biodiversity conservation and integrated 
water resources management (IWRM) in Yunnan (including knowledge of threats, priorities, and 
institutional frameworks); (iii) an established geographic information system (GIS) and database, 
mapping facilities and relevant data layers for Yunnan (including protected areas, rivers, and 
roads); and (iv) international expertise in conservation planning. Under the supervision of Asian 
Development Bank and Yunnan Environment Protection Department (YEPD), the agency will (i) 
lead TA implementation, (ii) assemble and support the specialists, (iii) allocate office space, (iv) 
facilitate and promote the involvement of  civil society organizations, (v) support the active 
involvement  of  local  resource  personnel  (including  at  least  one  member  of  the  team  that 
prepared the first draft of the provincial biodiversity strategy), and (vi) utilize the agency’s pool of 
national and/or international expertise as necessary to achieve the TA outputs. It is estimated 
that the TA will require 4.50 person-months of international and 32.25 person-months of national 
specialist services respectively, for a total 36.75 person-months. 
 
B.  Terms of Reference 
 
2.  Conservation planning specialist and team leader (1 national, 9 person-months). The 
team leader will be responsible for the overall coordination and supervision of TA activities and 
outputs and daily liaison with the YEPD and other project stakeholders. The team leader will 
have (i) at least 10 years of national experience in biodiversity conservation planning and gap 
analysis; (ii) at least 5 years of experience in biodiversity conservation in Yunnan, including 
demonstrated  familiarity  with  the  institutional  framework,  provincial  policies  and  plans  for 
biodiversity in Yunnan, and IWRM; (iii) a doctorate degree and/or equivalent experience in 
conservation science; (iv) demonstrated ability to manage a team, prepare reports, facilitate 
workshops, and work with the government, civil society, and local communities; and (v) fluency 
in spoken and written English. Working closely with team members, the YEPD, and other 
stakeholders, the team leader will do the following: 
 (i)  Prepare the detailed TA methodology and work plan. 
(ii)  Lead TA implementation, including the coordination of team inputs and timely 
delivery of project outputs. 
(iii)  Act as the main liaison between the YEPD and the project team. 
(iv)  Review, edit, and compile the inputs of the other team members. 
(v)  Support the other team members in their assigned tasks. 
(vi)  Lead the team’s review of the first draft provincial strategy. 
(vii)  Lead the review of provincial institutional frameworks, relevant national plans and 
international agreements, biodiversity strategies and action plans (BSAPs) in the 
PRC and elsewhere, and international best practice in conservation planning. 
(viii)  Lead the revision of the draft provincial strategy and the drafting of the 5-year 
action plan. 
(ix)  Facilitate stakeholder meetings, TA planning workshops (inception, midterm, and 
final), and team meetings. 
(x)  Prepare and submit progress reports to the YEPD and Asian Development Bank, 
including inception, midterm, and final reports and brief semiannual progress 
reports.

Appendix 3  11 
(xi)  Assist in the development of a knowledge product on the BSAP, to be prepared 
by ADB and the YEPD, including input and review of the draft document. 
 
3.  Biodiversity conservation planning and vertebrate fauna specialist and deputy 
team  leader  (1  international,  3  person-months).  A  specialist  with  expertise  in  systematic 
conservation planning, gap analysis, and vertebrate fauna will support the national team leader. 
The  specialist  will  have  (i)  at  least  10  years  of  international  experience  in  systematic 
conservation  planning,  gap  analysis,  and  vertebrate  fauna  research  and  conservation;  (ii) 
experience in biodiversity conservation in the southwestern PRC; (iii) a doctorate degree in 
conservation science or equivalent experience and skills; (iv) demonstrated experience in gap 
analysis and the use of appropriate software such as Marxan (a conservation planning software 
program); (v) applied understanding of GIS for conservation planning; and (vi) fluency in spoken 
and written English and preferably proficiency in Chinese. Working closely with the team, the 
specialist will do the following: 
(i)  Assist the team leader and team in preparing the detailed TA methodology and 
work plan. 
(ii)  Conduct a threat analysis using available data and existing methodologies in 
collaboration  with  the  biodiversity  specialists  on  fauna,  vascular  plants,  and 
climate change. 
(iii)  Lead the gap analysis and species ranking (output 1) and support the inputs to 
be provided by the other team members (e.g., database development by the GIS 
specialist). 
(iv)  Lead the assessment of landscape-level approaches most relevant to the TA, in 
particular the assessment of key biodiversity areas in Yunnan Province. 
(v)  Support the national vertebrate fauna specialist in ranking species. 
(vi)  Support the team leader in reviewing the draft provincial strategy. 
(vii)  Assist the team leader in drafting the BSAP. 
(viii)  Participate in the inception workshop. 
 
4.  Biodiversity specialists, one on vertebrate fauna (mammals, birds, amphibians, 
reptiles) and one on vascular flora (2 national, 5.5 person-months each). The specialists will 
review the preliminary list of priority species and sites identified in the draft provincial strategy 
and lead the technical assessments for vertebrate fauna and vascular flora. They will have (i) at 
least 5 years of experience in vertebrate fauna or vascular flora conservation and research in 
Yunnan,  including  demonstrated  knowledge  of  threatened  wetland  and  terrestrial  species, 
IWRM, and relevant provincial policies and plans; (ii) a master’s degree in conservation science, 
ecology, and biology and/or equivalent experience and skills; (iii) demonstrated experience in 
conservation action planning; and (iv) proficiency in spoken and written English. Under the 
supervision of the team leader, the specialists will do the following: 
 (i)  Use or modify existing simple criteria to select species for analysis (e.g., national 
and global threatened species, umbrella species, endemic species, restricted-
range species, economically important species). 
(ii)  Compile additional ecological data as required to supplement data in the draft 
provincial  strategy  for  the  species  to  be  assessed,  especially  distributional 
records, and rank the reliability of records. 
(iii)  Review previous biological priority-setting exercises for Yunnan and integrate 
their lessons into the TA. 
(iv)  Supervise and provide on-the-job training to assistants for data compilation. 
(v)  Use or modify existing simple methods to rank threats and management priorities 
for target species.

12  Appendix 3 
(vi)  Work with the GIS specialist to compile records and prepare maps of species 
distribution. 
(vii)  Participate in the gap analysis to identify species and sites of highest provincial 
conservation priority. 
(viii)  Strengthen and/or prepare relevant sections of the provincial strategy and action 
plan. 
(ix)  Provide input to related technical tasks as requested by the team leader. 
 
5.  Climate change and biodiversity specialist (1 international, 1.5 person-months). The 
specialist will assess the impact of climate change on selected species and the provincial 
protected area network and identify recommendations for inclusion in the BSAP. The specialist 
will have (i) at least 5 years of experience in climate change and biodiversity impact assessment 
and/or modeling; (ii) demonstrated ability in the use of international climate modeling software 
(e.g., Climate Map); (iii) fluency in spoken and written English; and (iv) a doctorate degree in 
climate change and/or biodiversity conservation or equivalent experience and skills. Working 
closely with the national climate change and biodiversity specialist, the specialist will do the 
following: 
 (i)  Assess current and future vulnerability of biodiversity to climate change based on 
available  data  (e.g.,  on  distribution,  vegetation,  and/or  ecosystem  cover)  for 
target species and other available thematic data (e.g., precipitation, elevation, 
temperature ranges) in comparison with likely climate change impacts. 
(ii)  Model predicted changes to temperature, precipitation, and humidity in Yunnan, 
and likely changes in ecosystem cover. 
(iii)  Based on overlays of distributions of target species on current vegetative cover, 
protected areas, and projected changes in ecosystems, (a) determine, using 
available data or stated assumptions, if the protected area network is sufficient to 
maintain viable populations of target species and ecosystems; (b) determine, 
using available data or stated assumptions, if the protected area network is 
sufficiently large to maintain viability against predicted climate change impacts; (c) 
identify  actions  to  strengthen  resilience  and  adaptation  potential,  such  as 
enrichment planting and mitigating other environmental threats, and assess their 
feasibility and effectiveness; (d) identify and rank species and ecosystems at risk, 
accounting for the severity of threats, population size, reproduction rate, and 
migration and/or dispersal ability; and (e) identify methods for strengthening the 
protected area network against climate change such as expanding protected 
areas,  establishing  new  protected  areas  and  community  sites  or  biological 
corridors, reforestation, and changes in land zoning, and assess their feasibility 
and effectiveness. 
 
6.  Climate change and biodiversity specialist (1 national, 1.75 person-months). The 
specialist will collect and analyze data regarding the impact of climate change on selected 
species  and  the  provincial  protected  area  network  and  help  identify  recommendations  for 
inclusion in the BSAP. The specialist will have (i) at least 5 years of national experience in 
climate change research, (ii) demonstrated knowledge of relevant provincial policies and plans 
in Yunnan, (iii) fluency in spoken and written English, and (iv) a doctorate degree in climate 
change and/or biodiversity conservation or equivalent experience and skills. Working closely 
with the international climate change and biodiversity and GIS specialists, the specialist will do 
the following: 
(i)  Establish baseline data and materials for analyzing the protected area network 
under  climate  change,  including  vegetation  and/or  ecosystem  cover  and

Appendix 3  13 
distribution, the provincial protected area network, precipitation, elevation, and 
temperature ranges. 
(ii)  Combine  available  data  on  distribution,  vegetation,  and/or  ecosystem  cover 
regarding target species and sites with available thematic data (e.g., precipitation, 
elevation, temperature ranges) to compare likely climate change impacts. 
(iii)  Overlay existing vegetative cover and the provincial protected area network and 
calculate likely changes in percentages of ecosystem types across the province 
and in the protected network. 
(iv)  Overlay distributions of target species on current vegetative cover, protected 
areas, and projected changes in ecosystems. 
(v)  Provide  these  outputs  to  the  international  climate  change  and  biodiversity 
specialist and work together to analyze the protected area network with respect 
to  climate  change  impacts  and  management  responses,  including  viability, 
resilience, adaptation, and mitigation. 
 
7.  Social development specialist (1 national, 3 person-months). The specialist will review 
the relevant sections of the existing draft provincial strategy and ensure that links with poverty 
alleviation and local livelihoods, especially for ethnic communities, are included in the strategy 
and 5-year action plan. The specialist will have (i) at least 10 years of experience in Yunnan in 
poverty alleviation and working with ethnic communities; (ii) a master’s degree in social studies 
or a similar field or equivalent experience and skills; (iii) preferably, familiarity with GIS concepts 
and software; and (iv) proficiency in spoken and written English. The specialist will do the 
following: 
 (i)  Assist the GIS specialist in obtaining, updating, and/or developing data layers on 
the distribution of ethnic minorities, poverty-stricken zones, and natural areas that 
are sacred sites for minorities in Yunnan. 
(ii)  For the BSAP, work with team members to strengthen the strategies that link 
biodiversity  conservation  and  poverty  alleviation,  particularly  strategies  that 
recognize  sacred  sites,  empower  communities,  and  strengthen  community 
management of natural resources. 
(iii)  Provide input to related technical tasks as requested by the team leader. 
 
8.  Geographic  information  systems  specialist  (1  national,  5  person-months).  The 
specialist will support the development of a project database and decision support tools. The 
specialist  will  have  (i)  demonstrated  proficiency  in  at  least  one  international  GIS  software 
package (e.g., ArcInfo) and the ability to develop databases; (ii) ability to efficiently compile and 
harmonize large amounts of digital data; (iii) ability to produce high-quality decision support 
tools, especially maps; (iv) a master’s degree in GIS or equivalent experience and skills; and (v) 
proficiency in spoken and written English. Working with the rest of the team and the Yunnan 
Institute of Environmental Sciences, which is the section of the YEPD that houses its GIS staff 
and equipment, the specialist will do the following: 
 (i)  Review available digital data from the draft provincial strategy, as well as data 
requirements for the TA. 
(ii)  Develop a database and GIS tailored to TA outputs. 
(iii)  Develop the TA database in a format that can be transferred, with all data, to the 
YEPD upon TA completion. 
(iv)  Identify data sources, including Eco-Partners, a network of biodiversity data-
holders established by the Critical Ecosystem Partnership Fund. 
(v)  Obtain data layers required for the project  such as prefecture and/or county 
boundaries, towns, roads, protected areas, rivers, topography, vegetation, ethnic

14  Appendix 3 
minorities,  and  biodiversity  hotspots,  including  data  established  in  previous 
projects. 
(vi)  As far as possible, verify the accuracy of key data layers such as protected area 
boundaries and their status. 
(vii)  Develop data layers for key attributes that are identified by the team but may not 
exist, such as prefecture and/or county protected areas, community protected 
areas, key biodiversity areas, wetlands, and local sacred sites. 
(viii)  Input the ecological data to be provided by team members on target species and 
sites. 
(ix)  Prepare maps as required by team members, such as those showing species 
and habitat distribution and the protected area network. 
 
9.  Conservation finance specialist (1 national, 2.5 person-months). The specialist will 
lead the preparation of the budget for the 5-year action plan; identify potential financing sources 
such as the government, international cooperation, and private sector investments; and develop 
specific mechanisms to finance the BSAP. The specialist will have (i) at least 5 years  of 
experience in conservation finance, including eco-compensation, in the PRC; (ii) demonstrated 
expertise in financing natural resources management in the PRC, knowledge of national and/or 
provincial  natural  resources  management  funding  programs,  and  expertise  in  developing 
sustainable financing mechanisms for conservation programs such as conservation trust funds 
and identifying and/or securing local revenue streams; (iii) a master’s degree in finance or a 
similar field or equivalent experience and skills; and (iv) proficiency in spoken and written 
English. The specialist will do the following: 
 (i)  Identify funding options for the 5-year action plan, 2016–2020. 
(ii)  Identify, assess, and rank potential mechanisms for benefit-sharing, such as for 
local communities in protected areas. 
(iii)  Develop  at  least  three  alternative  financing  strategies  based  on  funding 
mechanisms in the PRC. 
(iv)  Design  and  implement  mechanisms  to  mobilize  greater  and  more  diverse 
financing from public, private, domestic, and international sources.

Appendix 4  15 
DRAFT OUTLINE OF THE FINAL REPORT 
 
The key output of the technical assistance will be a draft biodiversity strategy and action plan for 
Yunnan province. Below is the draft outline of the biodiversity strategy and action plan. 
 
SUMMARY 
 
I.  INTRODUCTION 
A  Background 
B.  National Biodiversity Strategy and Action Plan 
 
II.  PREPARATION OF THE BIODIVERSITY STRATEGY AND ACTION PLAN 
A.  Approach 
B.  Development of the Vision and Goals 
C.  Data Compilation and Mapping 
D.  Gap Analysis of the Provincial Protected Area Network 
E.  Ranking Methods for Species and Sites 
F.  Participatory Planning and Workshops 
 
III.  BIODIVERSITY AND CONSERVATION IN YUNNAN PROVINCE 
A.  Biodiversity Values 
B.  Threats to Biodiversity 
C.  Institutional Framework 
D.  Conservation Initiatives 
 
IV.  CONSERVATION PLANNING AND BEST PRACTICES 
A.  Other Biodiversity Strategy and Action Plans in the People’s Republic of China 
B.  Conservation Planning in the Greater Mekong Subregion and Globally 
C.  Lessons Learned 
D.  Guiding Principles for Preparing the Yunnan Biodiversity Strategy and Action 
Plan 
 
V.  THE BIODIVERSITY STRATEGY AND ACTION PLAN, 2016–2020 
A.  Vision and Goals 
B.  Strategies and Five-Year Targets 
C.  Implementation Arrangements 
D.  Priority Projects for 2016–2020 
E.  Five-Year Work Plan and Budget 
 
APPENDICES 
 
1.  Ranking of Species and Sites 
2.  Gap Analysis of Protected Areas 
3.  Existing Protected Area Network 
4.  Proposed Revision of Protected Area Network

author_page:
CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 22 November 2012) 
Currency unit  –  yuan (CNY) 
CNY1.00  =  $0.1606 
$1.00  =  CNY6.2258 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
BCLO  –  biodiversity conservation liaison office 
BSAP  –  biodiversity strategy and action plan 
GIS  –  geographic information system 
IWRM  –  integrated water resources management 
NBSAP  –  national biodiversity strategy and action plan 
PRC  –  People’s Republic of China 
TA  –  technical assistance 
YEPD  –  Yunnan Environment Protection Department  
YPG  –  Yunnan provincial government 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
Type  –  Policy and advisory technical assistance (PATA) 
Targeting classification  –  Targeted intervention – Geographic (TI-G)  
Sector (subsectors)  –  Agriculture and natural resources (land-based natural resources 
management,  water-based  natural  resources  management, 
forestry) 
Theme (subthemes)  –  Environmental sustainability (natural resources conservation, 
global  and  regional  transboundary  environmental  concerns), 
capacity development (institutional development) 
Location (impact)  –  Rural (high), urban (low), national (medium), regional (medium) 
Partnership  –  Multi-Donor Trust Fund under the Water Financing Partnership 
Facility 
 
NOTE 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
Vice-President  S. Groff, Operations 2 
Director General  R. Wihtol, East Asia Department (EARD) 
Director  Y. L. Feng, Environment, Natural Resources, and Agriculture Division, EARD 
   
Team leader  M. Bezuijen, Environment Specialist, EARD 
Team members  K. Guy, Young Professional, EARD 
C. Yeager, Climate Change Specialist, EARD 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.
